comments.author: george.carstoiu@gmail.com
comments.text:
User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; rv:2.0b9pre) Gecko/20110109 Firefox/4.0b9pre
Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; rv:2.0b9pre) Gecko/20110109 Firefox/4.0b9pre

When "Open new tab" button is placed in default location, dragging a tab over it does not duplicate that respective tab, but instead places it last in the tab bar. (Litmus Testcase ID #12800)  

Reproducible: Always

Steps to Reproduce:
1.Open a few tabs
2.Drag one on to the new tab button

Actual Results:  
Tab is dropped last in the tab bar.

Expected Results:  
A duplicate of that tab is opened.
comments.creator: george.carstoiu@gmail.com
comments.raw_text:
User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; rv:2.0b9pre) Gecko/20110109 Firefox/4.0b9pre

When "Open new tab" button is placed in default location, dragging a tab over it does not duplicate that respective tab, but instead places it last in the tab bar. (Litmus Testcase ID #12800)  

Reproducible: Always

Steps to Reproduce:
1.Open a few tabs
2.Drag one on to the new tab button

Actual Results:  
Tab is dropped last in the tab bar.

Expected Results:  
A duplicate of that tab is opened.

comments.author: hskupin@gmail.com
comments.raw_text: Does it work when you drop it in the middle of the new tab button?
comments.creator: hskupin@gmail.com
comments.text: Does it work when you drop it in the middle of the new tab button?

comments.raw_text: No, it does not work. The only way to make it work is to change the default position of the "New tab" button.
comments.creator: george.carstoiu@gmail.com
comments.text: No, it does not work. The only way to make it work is to change the default position of the "New tab" button.
comments.author: george.carstoiu@gmail.com

comments.text: Confirmed. If I drag the new tab button out of the tab strip onto the navigation bar or add-on bar dragging a tab onto it does duplicate the tab but without the tab history of back/forward.
comments.creator: luke.iliffe@gmail.com
comments.raw_text: Confirmed. If I drag the new tab button out of the tab strip onto the navigation bar or add-on bar dragging a tab onto it does duplicate the tab but without the tab history of back/forward.
comments.author: luke.iliffe@gmail.com

comments.text: Does it also happen for tabs on bottom?
comments.creator: hskupin@gmail.com
comments.raw_text: Does it also happen for tabs on bottom?
comments.author: hskupin@gmail.com
george.carstoiu@gmail.com
comments.raw_text: Yes, same behavior with tabs on bottom.
comments.creator: george.carstoiu@gmail.com
comments.text: Yes, same behavior with tabs on bottom.

comments.author: hskupin@gmail.com
comments.text: It even doesn't work for me with Firefox 3.5.x on OS X. Could be an issue which hasn't been worked since the new tab button has been changed. And I can't imagine that we do not have an already filed bug.
comments.creator: hskupin@gmail.com
comments.raw_text: It even doesn't work for me with Firefox 3.5.x on OS X. Could be an issue which hasn't been worked since the new tab button has been changed. And I can't imagine that we do not have an already filed bug.

comments.author: hskupin@gmail.com
comments.text: Please note that this is only the case when the button is placed onto the tabs toolbar. When it gets moved to another toolbar, the dropped tab will be duplicated.
comments.raw_text: Please note that this is only the case when the button is placed onto the tabs toolbar. When it gets moved to another toolbar, the dropped tab will be duplicated.
comments.creator: hskupin@gmail.com

comments.author: george.carstoiu@gmail.com
comments.text: Shouldn't it do the same thing wherever it is positioned?
comments.raw_text: Shouldn't it do the same thing wherever it is positioned?
comments.creator: george.carstoiu@gmail.com

comments.text: *** Bug 602405 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
comments.author: hskupin@gmail.com
comments.creator: hskupin@gmail.com

comments.text:
(In reply to comment #8)
> Shouldn't it do the same thing wherever it is positioned?

Yes, it has to. Just saying that we have a different behavior based on the position of the button.
